item.title: I.C.C. Judges Denounce Effect of Trump’s Sanctions
item.description: President Trump’s retaliation against top officials at the International Criminal Court has shut them out of American services and made even routine daily tasks a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons

media:content.media:credit: Peter Dejong/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague. U.S. sanctions come at a time when the court is investigating claims of atrocities in Afghanistan, Libya, Myanmar, Sudan, Ukraine and Venezuela, as well as Gaza.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Bears Took Big Swing on the Offensive Line, and It Really Paid Off
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 10, 2026.

item.title: Volkswagen Suffers More Than Rivals From Auto Industry Woes
item.description: The German automaker’s sales in the United States plunged last year, hit by tariffs and the end of tax credits for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

media:content.media:credit: Jens Schlueter/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Electric vehicles at a Volkswagen plant in Dresden, Germany. The company is an extreme example of how difficult it has been for foreign automakers to cope in the U.S. car market.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 10, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 10, 2026.

item.title: Judge Bars Trump From Withholding Election Funds to States
item.description: The ruling is the latest legal setback to President Trump’s sweeping effort to compel changes to state election standards.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Voters last year in Dearborn, Mich. “The Constitution assigns no authority to the president over federal election administration,” the judge wrote in his ruling.

item.title: Trump Calls for 10 Percent Credit Card Interest Cap, After Killing Other Fee Limits
item.description: The president revived a campaign promise he has not actively pursued since taking office.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: After President’s Capture, U.S. and Venezuela Explore Restoring Diplomatic Ties
item.description: The move embodied the contradictions and fast-changing nature of the two countries’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2019.

item.title: Go for Another Round
item.description: Kameron Austin Collins treats us to a new construction, with more to come.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Kelpies, 100-foot-tall sculptures designed by Andy Scott and installed at the entrance of a canal in Scotland.

item.title: Rare Comic Introducing Superman Sells Privately for $15 Million
item.description: The copy of Action Comics No. 1, published in 1938, was stolen from the actor Nicolas Cage in 2000 and recovered more than a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Wilson/Metropolis Collectibles Inc, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A copy of the comic that introduced Superman in 1938. Fewer than 100 copies are known to exist.

item.title: Russell Vought, CFPB Leader, Requests $145 Million for Agency He Wants to Eliminate
item.description: A federal judge ordered Russell T. Vought, the bureau’s acting director, to keep requesting funds for the financial watchdog’s operations.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Russell T. Vought, the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, outside the White House in September.

item.title: Minnesota Woman Dies After Shark Bite in U.S. Virgin Islands, Authorities Say
item.description: People at the beach went to the woman’s rescue and helped her ashore, the authorities said, but she died at a hospital.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:credit: Erika P. Rodríguez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The woman was at a beach on the island of St. Croix when a shark bit her, the authorities said.

item.title: What It Takes to Drill Into an Antarctic Glacier
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong meets with Paul Anker, a drilling engineer aboard the icebreaker Araon, to discuss the stakes, preparations and pressure of the mission to drill a hole in the Thwaites Glacier to measure the water beneath.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller, Leila Medina and Stephanie Swart

item.title: Trump Administration Freezes Food Stamps in Minnesota
item.description: The move was part of a broader effort to to freeze social services to some Democratic-led states amid a fraud investigation in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A food pantry in Minnesota last year.

item.title: Dr. Oz Visits California to Target ‘Fraud’
item.description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid, and Bill Essayli, a Los Angeles-based prosecutor, said they were investigating federally funded services.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan

media:content.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid, left, and Bill Essayli, the first assistant U.S. attorney for the Central District of California, said they would ramp up efforts to detect fraud in government programs.

item.title: Trump amenaza con tomar Groenlandia ‘por las malas’
item.description: El presidente Trump volvió a amenazar con la anexión por la fuerza de Groenlandia, “les guste o no”.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente Trump y miembros de su gabinete en la reunión con ejecutivos petroleros celebrada el viernes en la Casa Blanca.

item.title: New Cellphone Video Shows ICE Agent’s Perspective Before Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security posted a clip of the video on social media and said it was taken by the agent, who killed a 37-year-old woman in the shooting.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Hamed Aleaziz and Julie Bosman

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Officials blocked off an area near the shooting in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Urges Oil Companies to Speed Work in Venezuela
item.description: The president met with executives on a day when the U.S. seized another tanker carrying Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Eric Schmitt and Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at a meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Iran Convulsed in Second Night of Nationwide Protests
item.description: Large marches against the government occurred despite an internet blackout and threats of a severe crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

media:content.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators marched in Tehran in an image taken from a social media post that was shared on Thursday.

item.title: Mohammed Harbi, Who Rewrote Algeria’s History, Dies at 92
item.description: He was an official in the revolutionary government, then, after the country won independence from France, was imprisoned and eventually wrote from exile.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Officials From Freezing Billions in Social Services Funds
item.description: The ruling temporarily halted plans to freeze more than $10 billion in funds for anti-poverty programs bound for five Democratic-led states.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague and Minho Kim

media:content.media:credit: Mark Vancleave/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Children watching television at ABC Learning Center in Minneapolis in December. Minnesota is one of the states that was targeted for a freeze in child care subsidies and other funds.

item.title: Outside Prisons in Caracas, Venezuelans Anxiously Await Release of More Political Detainees
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government said it would release an “important number” of imprisoned people, but only nine have been confirmed freed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Family members awaiting the release of prisoners outside El Helicoide, a notorious prison in the center of Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Owner of Swiss Bar Detained in Fire Investigation
item.description: Prosecutors in Switzerland ordered Jacques Moretti to be detained after investigators questioned him and his wife, Jessica Moretti. Officials are looking into whether negligence played a role in last week’s deadly fire at their bar, Le Constellation.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Umit Bektas/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Jacques and Jessica Moretti, the owners of the Swiss bar that burned in a deadly fire last week, in Sion, Switzerland, on Friday.

item.title: Gavin Newsom on Democrats, 2028 and His Fruit-Only Breakfasts
item.description: The California governor is powered by smoothies and bursting with thoughts about U.S. politics.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gavin Newsom

item.title: Trump Threatens to Take Greenland ‘the Hard Way’
item.description: The president continued to advance an imperialist vision of American foreign policy, where the U.S. can dominate neighboring countries “whether they like it or not.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at the meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Trump Pressures Oil Giants to Invest in Venezuela
item.description: Also, protests spread across Iran. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump with oil executives in the East Room at the White House.

item.title: Mamdani’s First Big Move to Help Renters Is Dealt a Blow by Court
item.description: Summit Properties USA won an auction on Friday to buy more than 5,000 apartments out of bankruptcy from the Pinnacle Group despite City Hall’s efforts to intervene.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Union of Pinnacle Tenants protested Summit Properties USA’s effort to buy Pinnacle Group properties on Thursday. Both companies appear to have many reported housing violations.

item.title: Mamdani Condemns Slurs and Pro-Hamas Chant at Heated Queens Protest
item.description: Pro-Palestinian and pro-Israel demonstrators hurled threats at each other outside an event promoting real estate sales in Jerusalem. The mayor said those actions had “no place in our city.”
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Nate Schweber
item.category: Agudath Israel of America;World Agudath Israel

media:content.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The protesters squared off on Thursday night across police barricades in front of a synagogue in Kew Gardens Hills, a neighborhood with a sizable population of Orthodox Jews.

item.title: Washington National Opera Is Leaving the Kennedy Center
item.description: The opera, which has performed at the arts center since 1971, was concerned about declines in attendance and donations during President Trump’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Washington National Opera officials contend that exiting the Kennedy Center would also give it more control over programming decisions.

item.title: Hessy Levinsons Taft, Jewish Baby on Cover of Nazi Magazine, Dies at 91
item.description: Without her parents’ knowledge, her portrait was entered as a prank in a contest in 1935 to represent the ideal Aryan infant — and she won.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Trump’s $100 Billion Venezuela Oil Plan Gets a Cool Reception
item.description: President Trump met with oil and gas executives on Friday in an effort to push them to invest money in Venezuela, a plan many of them are reluctant to embrace.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump during a meeting with energy executives at the White House on Friday. He wants the biggest U.S. and European oil companies to pour at least $100 billion into Venezuela.

item.title: A Look at Iran’s Antigovernment Protests
item.description: Protests have rocked Iran in recent weeks, and the country’s supreme leader has threatened to escalate a crackdown on demonstrators. Erika Solomon, our bureau chief for Iran and Iraq, discusses what’s fueling the protests with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Katrin Bennhold, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, Parin Behrooz and Sanjana Varghese

item.title: Bahram Beyzaie, Filmmaker Who Led Iran’s New Wave, Dies at 87
item.description: Despite a ceaseless battle against government censors, he was celebrated as one of his country’s greatest auteurs, winning praise from luminaries like Martin Scorsese.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: What Is the War Powers Resolution, and Why Is Trump’s Claim About It Misleading?
item.description: The resolution created different sections of statutory code. A part the Senate is weighing using has not been widely seen as unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The War Powers Resolution is a set of statutes Congress enacted in 1974 — and tweaked in 1983 — in an effort to reclaim its constitutionally intended role of deciding if the United States would go to war.

item.title: An Up-Close Look at the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: From an icebreaker sailing near the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica, our photographer has captured the many faces of the ice.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Mamdani Responds Cautiously After the Police Kill 2 People in One Night
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani did not call the shootings justified, but said New York Police officers were placed in “incredibly difficult and dangerous circumstances.”
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman and Maria Cramer

media:content.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: On Friday, New York Mayor Zohran Mamdani repeated plans for a new agency that would respond to mental health crises in the wake of two fatal shootings by the police.

item.title: 220,000 Fewer Workers: How Trump’s Cuts Affected Every Federal Agency
item.description: New data offers the first clear view of the impact of the buyouts and firings.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger, Francesca Paris and Alicia Parlapiano

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: 100 años de batalla por el petróleo venezolano
item.description: El sector petrolero del país ha experimentado grandes cambios y dos oleadas de nacionalizaciones desde que su primer pozo empezó a bombear en 1914.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Plataformas petrolíferas operadas por la empresa estatal Petróleos de Venezuela en la ciudad de Cabimas. Venezuela alberga algunos de los mayores yacimientos de petróleo del mundo.

item.title: Mamdani Says Theater Should Not Be ‘a Luxury’ as He Hands Out Free Tickets
item.description: The mayor said a new initiative by the Under the Radar festival exemplified an arts affordability agenda that he intends to pursue.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.category: Brooklyn College, City University of New York

media:content.media:credit: Reece Williams for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, with Kaneza Schaal and Meropi Peponides, right, co-creative directors of the festival, outside the Leonard and Claire Tow Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

item.title: Minneapolis Mayor Calls for State Role in Deadly ICE Shooting
item.description: With the Minneapolis area in a state of upheaval, Minnesota officials renewed their calls on Friday for state agents to be allowed to help investigate the fatal shooting of a woman by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer earlier this week.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A security guard spoke with federal immigration officers who were searching for someone near a shopping center in Minneapolis on Friday.

item.title: Measles Cases Spike in South Carolina
item.description: The outbreak has now spread to more than 300 people, most of them children.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth

item.title: Man Stole Dozens of Skeletons From Pennsylvania Cemetery, Authorities Say
item.description: Investigators recovered what was believed to be more than “100 full or partial sets of human and skeletal remains” from the man’s home and storage unit in Lancaster County, the district attorney said.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Christine Hauser

item.title: Venezuela entierra a las víctimas de la incursión de EE. UU.
item.description: La muerte tocó a las puertas de varias familias que, relacionadas o no con el régimen del depuesto presidente Maduro, se convirtieron en daño colateral de una operación militar.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Amigos y familiares en el entierro de Rosa Elena González, de 80 años, quien murió durante la incursión estadounidense para capturar al presidente de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: With Missile Strike on Ukraine, Putin Delivers a Warning to Europe
item.description: A nuclear-capable missile fired into Ukraine near Poland sent a message to Europe days after its leaders agreed to postwar security guarantees, Russian analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

media:content.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Damage to an apartment building in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, after a strike on Friday.

item.title: Día 1: ¿cuánto sabes sobre la salud de tu cerebro?
item.description: Nunca es demasiado pronto ni demasiado tarde para iniciar hábitos cerebrales saludables. Hoy, pon a prueba tus conocimientos con un cuestionario.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith

item.title: Joel Habener, Whose Research Led to Weight-Loss Drugs, Dies at 88
item.description: His discovery of the protein fragment GLP-1 was crucial in the development of Ozempic, Wegovy and other blockbuster obesity and diabetes treatments.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: This Popular Ghanaian Street Food Harnesses the Plantain’s Power
item.description: Yewande Komolafe’s oven-roasted take on kelewele pairs the classic snack with crisp shallots and herbs.
item.dc:creator: Yewande Komolafe

media:content.media:credit: Julia Gartland for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.
media:content.media:description: Perhaps the most mouthwatering iteration of plantains is kelewele, a spicy, sweet, crunchy, caramelized-to-perfection street snack from Ghana.

item.title: X Sues Music Publishers, Alleging ‘Collusion’ Over Licensing Deals
item.description: The social media platform says it was pressured into licensing agreements for songs “at inflated rates.” In 2023, publishers sued the company for copyright violations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario

media:content.media:credit: Evelyn Hockstein/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Starting in 2021, Twitter, now known as X, had been exploring licensing deals with the major music conglomerates, but those talks stalled once Elon Musk took the platform over.

item.title: Christopher Raia to Be FBI Deputy Director After Bongino’s Departure
item.description: Even as the selection of a career agent, Christopher G. Raia, leaves an unusual three-person leadership structure in place, it returns a career agent to the No. 2 post.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, William K. Rashbaum and Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Adam Gray for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Christopher G. Raia was a Coast Guard officer before he joined the F.B.I. As an agent, he spent much of his career in Texas, rising through the ranks from investigating violent crime to managing counterterrorism work.

item.title: Compass Acquires Top Rival, Creating World’s Largest Brokerage
item.description: First signed into agreement in September 2025, the merger brings together the largest and second-largest real estate firms in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Dorie Chevlen

media:content.media:credit: Joe Hendrickson/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Seeks New Powers to Pressure ‘Underperforming’ Weapons Makers
item.description: In an executive order, President Trump is aiming to punish defense contractors that don’t deliver weapons quickly enough.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said this week that he was putting defense contractors on notice that they had to start producing weapons faster.
